People
The Goombay Festival is a time of celebration and reunion. It’s when former residents return to reconnect with friends, family and neighbors. It is chance to celebrate the area’s Bahamian roots that date back to the 1800s and to be a part of a cultural tradition that began in 1977. It is three days of family-friendly fun filled with great food and music and energizing Junkanoo rushes. Below is a selection of photos that capture the joy this annual event brings to Little Bahamas of Coconut Grove.
(L) Goombay Queen, Traci Young-Byron at Armbrister Park on the opening night of the Goombay Festival, Coconut Grove, Florida, 2024. Photo by Yaasmeen Johnson.
(R) Goombay King, Dr. Richard Holton on Grand Avenue, Coconut Grove, Florida, 2024. Photo by Paola Katherine Rodriguez.
Along Grand Avenue, festivalgoers bring tents and chairs to settle in for a day filled with music, food and Junkanoo rushes. (L) Photo by Mariela Gonzalez (M) Photo by Enrique Rosell (R) Photo by Jason Smith
Festival goers dressed in T-shirts celebrating Goombay and Coconut Grove.
(L) Armbrister Park, Coconut Grove, Florida, 2024. Photo by Fernanda Romero (M) Grand Avenue, Coconut Grove, Florida, 2024. Photo by Mariela Gonzalez (R) Grand Avenue, Coconut Grove, Florida, 2024.Photo by Mariela Gonzalez taken on Grand Avenue
Grand Avenue, Coconut Grove, Florida, 2024. Photos by Paola Katherine Rodriguez.
(L) Festivalgoers join a Junkanoo rush, Grand Avenue, Coconut Grove, Florida, 2024. Photos by Lisbeth Moquete. (R) Grand Avenue, Coconut Grove, Florida, 2024. Photo by Yaasmeen Johnson.
(L) A festivalgoer records a Junkanoo rush Grand Avenue, Coconut Grove, Florida, 2024. Photo by Yaasmeen Johnson. (R) A vendor sells souvenirs Grand Avenue, Coconut Grove, Florida, 2024. Photo by Mariela Gonzalez.
Grand Avenue, Coconut Grove, Florida, 2024. Photos by Enrique Rosell.
(L) Parents push strollers down Grand Avenue, Coconut Grove, Florida, 2024. Photo by Jason Smith. (R) People walk past the Abaco building on Grand Avenue and Plaza Street, Coconut Grove, Florida, 2024. Photo by Jason Smith.
People gather at Grand and Douglas as a performer takes to the stage. The picture on the left captures a colorfully painted building that used to be The Tiki Club. Coconut Grove, Florida, 2024. Photos by Jason Smith.
(L) Three generations of Groveites on the opening night of the Goombay Festival at Armbrister Park, Coconut Grove, Florida, 2024. Photo by Enrique Rosell. (M) Two friends pose for a photo in front of the Ace Theater on Grand Avenue, Coconut Grove, Florida, 2024. Photo by Yaasmeen Johnson. (R) A group poses for a photo in front of the Queen Supermarket mural on Grand Avenue, Coconut Grove, Florida, 2024. Photo by Paola Katherine Rodriguez

Upcoming Events
Events in the community:
Printing with natural dyes,
July 5 & 19, August 16 & 30 at the Kamopong National Botanical Garden
Visit the Kampong National Botanical Garden and create beautiful prints by experimenting with Shibori, a Japanese resist dyeing technique and by using the cyanotype sunlight printing technique.
Community Collections Grant Symposium at the Library of Congress
On September 24, Dr. Aarti Mehta-Kroll and Dr. Rebecca Friedman will do a presentation about their project: Documenting Goombay and Little Bahamas of Coconut Grove in the Mumford Room (LM-649), located on the 6th floor of the James Madison Building of the Library of Congress in Washington, DC.
Previous Events
Coconut Grove Crisis Food Pantry Fundraiser, May 22, 2025
The Women’s Club of Coconut Grove in Partnership with the Rotary Club of Coconut Grove will be hosted their 3
rd
annual Goombay Party benefiting the
Coconut Grove Food Crisis Pantry
on May 22.
Family Fun Day, May 24, 2025
May 24th was Family Fun Day at Esther Mae Armbrister Park. Participants enjoyed Junkanoo performances, BBQ, music and arts and crafts. Rack’z BBQ won the barbeque coookoff
Documenting Goombay and Little Bahamas of Coconut Grove Exhibition, June 1 and June 7, 2025
The Wolfsonian Public Humanities Lab at FIU, in partnership with the Sanctuary of the Arts at St. Mary’s Missionary Baptist Church and Miami Dade College Gibson Center will be organized an exhibition of photographs titled “Documenting Goombay and Little Bahamas of Coconut Grove”. The photos were on display at 136 Frow Avenue, Coral Gables on June 1, from 1pm to 5pm.
HistoryMiami Museum
joined us to gather stories. The exhibition continued at the Miami Dade College Gibson Center on June 7 during the Miami Goombay Festival.

Support Us
The Goombay Festival brings together people from across South Florida and beyond to enjoy three days of great food, music and Bahamian culture. To learn more about how you can support this unique Miami tradition,
please review our sponsorship opportunities for Goombay 2025
. In addition to becoming a festival sponsor, you can also support the festival by providing in-kind contributions or becoming a volunteer. For more information, please
contact us
.
